Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions IRCN: A Research Coordination Network for Biodiversity of Ciliates
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ciliates are a major group of unicellular, eukaryotic organisms (protists) that play important roles in nearly all ecosystems and serve as model organisms for basic research in genetics and cell function. Approximately 7500 species are known, but three times that many may be undiscovered, especially in poorly explored places like tropical forests or the deep ocean. Better knowledge of the biodiversity of ciliates would translate into more effective management of ecosystems or new model organisms for biomedical research, but achieving this has been slower and more difficult than has been the case for multicellular organisms. Modern studies of biodiversity often use DNA from preserved specimens but there is no such archive for ciliates. Also, sequencing most genes has been more challenging for ciliates than for animals or plants. Lastly, researchers who study biodiversity of ciliates are scattered thinly and unevenly across the world, and many are younger investigators who have little money for traveling to meetings or other laboratories to build collaborations.

The International Research Coordination Network for Biodiversity of Ciliates (IRCN-BC) will be an international collaboration that will lower barriers to research on ciliate biodiversity, generate new collaborations, establish procedures for archiving material, and, most significantly, stimulate research that will unite the taxonomic, genetic, and functional dimensions of biodiversity. The IRCN-BC will accomplish these goals by sponsoring workshops and symposia to build strategies and develop techniques, by creating archives for preserved samples of cells and DNA, by maintaining a website to report activities, attract new members, promote collaborations, and share data, and by funding travel for researchers. The IRCN-BC will be a model for accelerating multidimensional investigation of biodiversity in other protistan groups. Students at Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs) traditionally get scant exposure to areas of biology outside biomedicine. The IRCN-BC will create an email listserv of contacts at MSIs to inform faculty and students about the IRCN-BC, especially connections between biodiversity and biomedicine. Students from underrepresented minority groups (African-American, Pacific Islander) will be targeted for inclusion in two workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Communication is the heart of science, and this central component of research is addressed by the International Research Coordination Network for Biodiversity of Ciliates (IRCN-BC). Ciliates are one of the major groups of complex eukaryotic microbes known as protists. They include a wide array of specialized forms that are widespread and abundant in freshwater, marine, and terrestrial ecosystems, where they have influential roles as “ecosystem engineers”. The IRCN-BC is a jointly funded partnership between PI Clamp’s U.S. laboratory and the laboratory of Weibo Song at Ocean University of China that has the general objective of promoting research in the area of integrative biodiversity of ciliates. The Song lab was already the center of a loose collaborative network of Chinese, Korean, German, British, and Saudi Arabian researchers. The Clamp lab had established collaborations with researchers in the U.S., Mexico, Brazil, and China. 

Together, the two labs provided a nucleus for a more formal network of specialists that would be able to accomplish the ambitious objectives of the project, which were the following:

1) Facilitate discovery of ciliates in areas other than western Europe and eastern North America, the only geographic regions in which the ciliate fauna is well known;

2) Recruit new members from all countries, especially those that are poorly represented in research on biodiversity of ciliates;

3) Focus on problems that hinder progress in research on ciliate biodiversity;

4) Build relationships between investigators;

5) Become an ‘engine’ for generating new collaborations, new ideas for research projects, new procedures for archiving material, new proposals for research, and new types of interdisciplinary cooperation; and 

6) Advance the rate at which knowledge is gained about taxonomy, phylogeny, geographical distribution, ecology, and genomics of core groups of ciliated protists 

We accomplished these objectives by sponsoring the following broad range of activities during the period of funding:   

1) Hosted a series of four annual workshops and one symposium that focused on techniques or strategies used to investigate integrative biodiversity of ciliates and provided opportunities for face-to-face networking.  Each workshop had a specific theme that, taken together, encompassed the scope of the project. They were held in different regions of the world to make it easier for young researchers with limited means to attend. 

2) Increased the membership of the network. There is no formal membership in the network; members could more accurately be defined as associates and users.  This number has grown from approximately 50 to approximately 125 in the last six years. 

3) Provided guidance to researchers by defining integrative biodiversity in a precise way because discussion of the concept in scientific articles has led to a number of different ideas of what it includes. Also, we generated a list of Grand Challenges of Biodiversity of Ciliates that provide a specific list of theoretical and logistical problems most worthy of investigation that will enable researchers to focus on more well-defined goals.

4) Created a website that will provide a variety of resources to researchers in biodiversity of ciliates, including information and news about meetings and academic opportunities, collaborations, and research findings.

5) Funded many young researchers over a period of six years to enable them to attend workshops of the IRCN-BC and scientific conferences.  A small number of young researchers also were funded for travel to a laboratory for advanced training or research collaboration in every year of the grant.

6) Decided to continue the network past the funding period as a formally recognized section of the International Society of Protistologists. This contributes to our goal of becoming a model network and will enable us to function as an “umbrella” organization for all protistologists with an interest in biodiversity of ciliates.  Already this association has borne fruit by enabling us to co-sponsor a symposium on biodiversity of ciliates that will meet in Delhi, India in April, 2018.  We also helped organize a group of researchers who will advise the UniEuk project on any issues that pertain to ciliates as it builds a new, more accessible, permanently maintained database for rRNA sequences of eukaryotic organisms.

7) Explored development of species of ciliates as research models for experimental investigation of aspects of biodiversity that are not used now as models in a network-sponsored symposium at the XIV International Congress of Protistology (2013) and presentations at all annual workshops.

8) Held two workshops of the IRCN-BC at Minority-Serving Institutions (MSIs) that were attended by some students from under-represented minorities.  In addition, a student was employed for one semester to update a listserv of academic contacts at MSIs and other institutions with significant minority enrollment that will be used to inform faculty and students about biodiversity of ciliates and the IRCN-BC.
